------=_NextPart_000_022A_01CD11B3.74F89A00
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

All this reminds me of the numerous discussions about media-types - whether=
 or not they should carry any domain specific information, something which =
I have always had a hard time trying to understand fully.

Is it fair to sa=
y that those who think media-types can and should carry some kind of domain=
 semantics thinks in terms of the semantic web - they want the resources to=
 be self descriptive, but not only in terms of the processing model - also =
in terms of the semantics?

I myself have belonged to that group without kn=
owing it - having that feeling of, hmmm, how can you work with resources wi=
thout knowing what they actually represent? But some valuable input from Da=
rrel Miller and Mike Kelly (https://groups.google.com/d/msg/hypermedia-web/=
V0hcWwQet3I/FdYY1PGUTgMJ) and this (to me) recent focus on REST vs. SemWeb =
has helped quite a bit understanding the differences. Thanks.

/J=F8rn

  -=
---- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jorn Wildt 
  To: rest-discuss@yahoogr=
oups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, April 03, 2012 10:29 AM
  Subject: [rest-discuss=
] REST vs. Linked Data


    
  It seems like there is an ongoing debate/mi=
smatch/battle/whatever between REST and Linked Data (if I am interpreting v=
arious Tweets correct). Could anyone share a link to something that can enl=
ighten me on what this is about?

  Thanks, J=F8rn
